pullRequest.body:
In this PR, we ported a part of Andrew Yang's lean3 repository at [this repository](https://github.com/erdOne/lean-AG-morphisms), which is appoved by @erdOne after his discussion with @chrisflav.

Andrew defined `min_generator_card` and `spanrank` in this repository (it's at /dimension_theory/min_generator_card), we ported this, and ported some basic lemmas about it.

Co-authored-by:
@erdOne
@xyzw12345 [wangjt2020@163.com](mailto:wangjt2020@163.com)
@jjdishere [emailboxofjjd@163.com](mailto:emailboxofjjd@163.com)
@Blackfeather007 [2100017455@stu.pku.edu.cn](mailto:2100017455@stu.pku.edu.cn)

--- 
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

Thank you very much for your review comments! I have modified it according to your suggestion. In particular, `minGeneratorCard` has been renamed by `spanRankNat`. Please let me know if there's anything else that needs to be changed!

messageFile.md

messageFile.md

### PR summary [634f820c6a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20744/commits/634f820c6a3991d71bd5e718f54c6289733a3926)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Module.SpanRank` (new file)|1174|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Basis.mk_eq_spanRank`
`+ FG.exists_span_set_encard_eq_spanFinrank`
`+ FG.generators_mem`
`+ FG.generators_ncard`
`+ FG.spanRank_le_iff_exists_span_set_card_le`
`+ card_le_of_injective''`
`+ cast_toNat_eq_iff_lt_aleph0`
`+ exists_span_set_card_eq_spanRank`
`+ fg_iff_spanRank_eq_spanFinrank`
`+ generators`
`+ generators_card`
`+ instance (p : Submodule R M) : Nonempty {s : Set M // span R s = p} := ⟨⟨p, by simp⟩⟩`
`+ linearIndependent_le_span''`
`+ rank_eq_spanRank_of_free`
`+ rank_le_spanRank`
`+ spanFinrank`
`+ spanFinrank_eq_iInf`
`+ spanFinrank_span_le_ncard_of_finite`
`+ spanRank`
`+ spanRank_bot`
`+ spanRank_eq_zero_iff_eq_bot`
`+ spanRank_finite_iff_fg`
`+ spanRank_span_le_card`
`+ spanRank_sup_le_sum_spanRank`
`+ spanRank_toENat_eq_iInf_encard`
`+ spanRank_toENat_eq_iInf_finset_card`
`+ span_generators`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks for the comments! We've made some changes accordingly, added several lemmas, and also renamed `minGenerator` as `spanBasis`.
If you merge `master` into this branch then you'll stop all those stupid `messageFile.md` messages, by the way.

> A couple of comments:
> 
> * can you get rid of all `Fintype` and only use `Finite` (if this is too complicated don't worry)?
> * why using `Fin p.spanFinrank → M` instead of a `Set M` of the relevant cardinality?
> * Can you link your notions to `Module.rank`, at least in some cases? If it's too much work add a `TODO`.
> 
> Thanks!

Thanks for the comment, it appears that the first two suggestions actually coincides - the `Fintype` is created in order to make the indexed map. Luckily, things worked out really well after refactoring everything to `Set M`. I totally agree that we should add some lemmas to link it to `Module.rank`, but perhaps we could move that to a separate PR?

I noticed that `Module.rank` is implemented to take value as a `Cardinal`, do you think we should define `Module.spanRank` to be a `Cardinal` as well? @riccardobrasca @erdOne @chrisflav 

Edit: Already refactored to Cardinal, so another round of review might be needed.

Edit: The third suggestion is being implemented now, but may need to wait for a while.
Sorry, I am a little busy at the moment. Can you please fix the error?
Lemmas that links `spanRank` to `Module.rank` have been added. We finished the proof of these lemmas and added some docstring about them. (The error is fixed now)

> A general question: why speaking about submodules rather than simply a module?

Well, I didn't really think about this issue at first (since we're porting @erdOne 's repo). But if I have to give a reason, I think it's because `Submodule.FG` is defined first and then `Module.Finite` is defined using it?

> > A general question: why speaking about submodules rather than simply a module?
> 
> Well, I didn't really think about this issue at first (since we're porting @erdOne 's repo). But if I have to give a reason, I think it's because `Submodule.FG` is defined first and then `Module.Finite` is defined using it?

Hmm, I don't see the point of talking about submodules. The rank (in any sense) is a property unrelated to any ambient space.

> > > A general question: why speaking about submodules rather than simply a module?
> > 
> > 
> > Well, I didn't really think about this issue at first (since we're porting @erdOne 's repo). But if I have to give a reason, I think it's because `Submodule.FG` is defined first and then `Module.Finite` is defined using it?
> 
> Hmm, I don't see the point of talking about submodules. The rank (in any sense) is a property unrelated to any ambient space.

OK, I guess I'll do the refactoring and call for another review when I finished, thanks!

> > > > A general question: why speaking about submodules rather than simply a module?
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Well, I didn't really think about this issue at first (since we're porting @erdOne 's repo). But if I have to give a reason, I think it's because `Submodule.FG` is defined first and then `Module.Finite` is defined using it?
> > 
> > 
> > Hmm, I don't see the point of talking about submodules. The rank (in any sense) is a property unrelated to any ambient space.
> 
> OK, I guess I'll do the refactoring and call for another review when I finished, thanks!

Let's see if @erdOne has an explanation, I may very well be wrong!
Sure! Let's see how this was initially designed.

One of the main application is to ideals so that is why I did it initially for submodules. I think there would be friction about `(top : Submodule R N)` and `N` or spanning in M versus N when N is itself a submodule. This can of course be solved by sufficient API so changing the def to modules could be fine as long as there are tailored lemmas for submodules. One thing you would definitely lose is dot notation but this is not that important IMO.

Thanks for the comment! @riccardobrasca what do you think about this? I think considering this design, and the fact that we have both `Submodule.FG` and `Module.Finite` for finitely-generated modules, probably we can keep this?

I think defining it for modules would boil down to the same construction but the submodule fixed to `\top`, since saying `s : Set M` generates `M` is expressed as `Submodule.span R s = \top`. So IMO it makes sense to develop it for an arbitrary submodule instead.

I may be wrong, but it seems very strange to me to speak about the rank of a submodule. Indeed, `Modules.rank` is for modules. You can ask on zulip, but what I am more or less sure is that we want the same convention for various notions of rank.

I think we can merge this and see if the difference wrt `Module.rank` creates friction later on (as you said the refactor should be easy). Can you add a note somewhere in the doc pointing out this asymmetry?


bors d+

:v: Xuchun-Li can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Thanks for all the review comments! The note has been added and I messaged the author of this PR to come and merge this.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13547873895/job/37863885920)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13547873895/job/37863886441)
Thanks a lot for all the porting work! I left some comments.
Sorry for suggesting changes to the basic defs so late but after thinking about this some more I feel like these might be more natural.

LGTM. Thanks a lot for doing this!
I shouldn't be the one maintainer-merging this though.
Thanks, last comments.

A couple of comments:
* can you get rid of all `Fintype` and only use `Finite` (if this is too complicated don't worry)?
* why using `Fin p.spanFinrank → M` instead of a `Set M` of the relevant cardinality?
* Can you link your notions to `Module.rank`, at least in some cases? If it's too much work add a `TODO`.

Thanks!
A general question: why speaking about submodules rather than simply a module?

```suggestion
* `minGeneratorCard`: The minimum cardinality of a generating set of a submodule as a natural number.
  If no finite generating set exists, the minimum cardinality is defined to be `0`.
```

Could you please use the nice `ENat` notation here? And explain the difference between `spanRank` and `minGeneratorCard`.

Also I am not sure about the naming. I think the two should be named similarly, maybe `Submodule.spanRank` and `Submodule.spanRankNat`?
Could you please also implement the `ℕ∞` part of my comment?

```suggestion
* `FG.exists_fun_minGeneratorCard_span_range_eq` : Any finitely generated submodule has a generating
  family of cardinality equal to `minGeneratorCard`.
```
And please also adapt the wording here.
Maybe `@[simp]`?
I don't think this lemma is needed.

```suggestion
/-- An arbitrarily chosen generating family of minimal cardinality. -/
noncomputable def FG.minGenerator {p : Submodule R M} (h : p.FG) : Fin p.minGeneratorCard → M :=
  Classical.choose (exists_fun_minGeneratorCard_span_range_eq h)
```

```suggestion
lemma FG.span_range_minGenerator {p : Submodule R M} (h : p.FG) :
```

```suggestion
lemma FG.minGenerator_mem {p : Submodule R M} (h : p.FG) (i) :
```

```suggestion
lemma fg_iff_spanrank_eq_minGeneratorCard {p : Submodule R M} :
```
Does the `simp` have to be squeezed here? In general, if it is a terminal `simp`, please avoid `simp only` if possible.
Do you need the `f'`? It seems, it is only used once and then unfolded immediatly in multiple places.

```suggestion
lemma fg_iff_spanRank_eq_spanRankNat {p : Submodule R M} :
```

Sorry, maybe my comments were not very clear. I don't think "span rank of a submodule" is a common term. I am fine with keeping it as the name of the `def`, because it is nice and short. But I think you should explain the term in the docstring and don't use it in the title. "Cardinality of minimal generating set of a submodule" for example.

```suggestion
  · intro e
    rw [← spanRank_ne_top_iff_fg, e]
    exact WithTop.coe_ne_top
```

```suggestion
    span R (Set.range (minGenerator h)) = p :=
```

```suggestion
lemma FG.minGenerator_mem {p : Submodule R M} (h : p.FG) (i : Fin p.spanRankNat) :
```

Sorry if my previous comment was unclear: The "don't squeeze `simp`" policy only refers to *terminal* `simp`s, i.e. that appear at the end of proofs. If it is in the middle of the proof, you should still use `simp only`. See https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#squeezing-simp-calls for more details.

```suggestion
    p.spanRank ≤ n ↔ ∃ f : Fin n → M, span R (Set.range f) = p := by
```

```suggestion
    ∃ f : Fin p.spanRankNat → M, span R (Set.range f) = p := by
```

Maybe it is helpful to read https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#structuring-definitions-and-theorems, in particular the paragraph:

> If the theorem statement requires multiple lines, indent the subsequent lines by 4 spaces. The proof is still indented only 2 spaces (not 6 = 4 + 2). When providing a proof in tactic mode, the by is placed on the line prior to the first tactic; however, by should not be placed on a line by itself. In practice this means you will often see := by at the end of a theorem statement.
`spanRankNat.proof_1` is a code smell. Does this indicate that you are missing some API?
I guess not really. It's simply the s.Finite part in {s // s.Finite ∧ span R s = p} stated in a pretty weird way (which we have already corrected it now).

```suggestion
  haveI t1 : Finite (@Set.Elem M s) := h₁
```
This is a proof, not data.
Thanks! We've fixed that one now

```suggestion
    exact ⟨fun _ ↦ 0, by simp⟩
```

```suggestion
    (Submodule.span R s).spanRank ≤ hs.toFinset.card := by
```
Can you define this as `(spanRank p).toNat` and show that it is equal to this?
And I think this should be called `spanFinrank` following `rank` and `finrank`.
Good name! Thanks for the suggestion! The lemmas have been updated now.

```suggestion
  ⨅ (s : Set M) (hs : span R s = p), s.encard
```
I think this might be a better definition?
Yeah, you're right! The definition has now been modified according to your suggestion.

```suggestion
```
I don't think this is a basis. perhaps just `FG.generators`?
This looks strange.
It's fixed now. That's probably something useless generated by automatic translation.
Try `Nat.cast_add`? Or perhaps `ENat.coe_add`.
Both actually worked! Thanks for the suggestion.

```suggestion
  simp_rw [← span_range_generators h]
```

```suggestion
In this file, we define the minimum cardinality of a generating set for a submodule, which is
```

```suggestion
/-- A submodule's `spanRank` is not top if and only if it is finitely generated. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- A submodule is finitely generated if and only if its `spanRank` is equal to its `spanFinrank`. -/
```
Also, maybe switch LHS and RHS? The RHS seems more complicated.

```suggestion
/-- The span of the generators equals the submodule. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The elements of the generators are in the submodule. -/
```

I don' think the proof should use `Submodule.FG.spanRank_le_iff_exists_span_range_eq` as this is a direct consequence of the definition:
```suggestion
lemma spanRank_span_le_encard (s : Set M) :
    (Submodule.span R s).spanRank ≤ s.encard :=
  biInf_le _ (by constructor)
```
Note also I replaced `(s : Set R)` by `(s : Set M)` and `hs.toFinset.card` by `s.encard` dropping the
`Set.Finite` assumption. Then you can have this as a finite version:
```
lemma spanFinrank_span_le_ncard_of_finite {s : Set M} (hs : s.Finite) :
    (span R s).spanFinrank ≤ s.ncard := by
  rw [← ENat.coe_le_coe]
  convert spanRank_span_set_finite (R := R) s
  · simpa [spanFinrank] using (⟨hs.toFinset, by simp⟩ : (span R s).FG)
  · exact hs.cast_ncard_eq
```
Thanks for the suggestion!

```suggestion
lemma spanRank_ne_top_iff_fg {p : Submodule R M} : p.spanRank ≠ ⊤ ↔ p.FG := by
```
If you want.

```suggestion
  let _ := h₁.fintype
```

```suggestion
  have temp : h₁.toFinset.card = Fintype.card (Set.Elem s) := by rw [Set.Finite.card_toFinset h₁]
```

```suggestion
/-- For a finitely generated submodule, its spanRank is less than or equal to `n`
```

```suggestion
  if and only if there are elements indexed by `Fin n` that generates the submodule. -/
```

```suggestion
theorem cast_toNat_eq_iff_lt_aleph0 {c : Cardinal} : (toNat c) = c ↔ c < ℵ₀ := by
```
Should be exactly the same.
Can you clarify the doc? I don't understand what "the infinite case" is.

```suggestion
  exact this.symm ▸ i
```
Here `apply this ▸ i` works, and I *think* that `exact this ▸ i` is also supposed to work (`▸` should be smart enough to reverse the direction of `this`). Maybe it is a bug. Feel free to ask on Zulip if you want.
I'll post a thread on zulip and ask when I have time to do so. It's actually surprising to know that `apply this ▸ i` worked because I used to think ` (a = b)▸` as only rewrite `a` to `b`. Thanks!
It a relatively recent (less than one year I think) feature of `▸`, it understands that one needs to do `rw [← ]`.
See https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/pull/4046
`f` can be implicit, but do as you prefer.
I choose to make `f` explicit because I think `f` would often need to be given explicitly when using this theorem, so I'll probably stick to the current version.
`v` can be implicit.
Thanks for the suggestion!

```suggestion
    exact fun i ↦ Span.repr R w ⟨v i, s ▸ trivial⟩
```

```suggestion
    exact lt_of_le_of_lt (ciInf_le' _ ⟨s, hs₂⟩) (by simpa)
```
Why not.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/Module): the minimum cardinality of generating set

This can of course be solved by sufficient API so changing the def to modules could be fine as long as there are tailored lemmas for submodules. One thing you would definitely lose is dot notation but this is not that important IMO.

Thanks for the comment! @riccardobrasca what do you think about this? I think considering this design, and the fact that we have both `Submodule.FG` and `Module.Finite` for finitely-generated modules, probably we can keep this?

I think defining it for modules would boil down to the same construction but the submodule fixed to `\top`, since saying `s : Set M` generates `M` is expressed as `Submodule.span R s = \top`. So IMO it makes sense to develop it for an arbitrary submodule instead.

I may be wrong, but it seems very strange to me to speak about the rank of a submodule. Indeed, `Modules.rank` is for modules. You can ask on zulip, but what I am more or less sure is that we want the same convention for various notions of rank.

I think we can merge this and see if the difference wrt `Module.rank` creates friction later on (as you said the refactor should be easy). Can you add a note somewhere in the doc pointing out this asymmetry?
